plugins.name: Smart Cloner
plugins.description:
Make multiple renamed copies of components, frames or other layers in seconds.


‚Ä¢ Choose direction with command and create any amount of copies at a time

‚Ä¢ Completely keyboard accessible: name and create all of the copies in one approach to the keyboard.

‚Ä¢ The part after the last ‚Äú/‚Äù is preselected automatically (use cmd/ctrl + a to select all if needed)

‚Ä¢ All copies would be selected and conveniently placed right under the prototype layer

‚Ä¢ Regulate distance between copies. Plugin remembers last value for the next time.


How to use:

1. Select one layer that you want to copy. Works with Components, Frames and other types of layers.

2. Call the plugin. The plugin has 4 different commands for cloning in all 4 directions.

3. Name your copies. Use tab for creating another copy, so you can name all of them in one approach to the keyboard.

4. (Optional) Hit Shift+Tab to focus on Shift input, then type the desired distance between the copies. The plugin will remember that value next time.

4. Hit Enter to create your copies.


Also, visit this thread for video demo: https://twitter.com/aswellasyouare/status/1169334638805958658

accepted.name: Vadim Pleshkov
accepted.description: Product Designer

plugins.tagline: Create named copy of a component or any other layer

plugins.name: Variable Importer/Exporter
plugins.description:
The Variable Importer/Exporter plugin is used to create variables with ease and export them to a single source of truth in a JSON file!


Overview


The Variable Variable Importer/Exporter Plugin enables users to import and export variable collections within Figma. This functionality facilitates the definition and management of design tokens such as colors, spacings, and other attributes, ensuring consistency across different projects and among team members.


JSON Structure


The JSON file used by the plugin consists of an array of collections. Each collection can include multiple variables defined under different modes and types.


Collections


- name: The name of the collection (e.g., "Colors", "Spacing Tokens").

- modes: An array defining the modes applicable to the variables (e.g., "Default").

- variables: An object containing the variables. Each variable can have multiple shades or sizes, each defined with its type and value(s).


NOTE: You can only have one mode per collection with a free account. To have multiple modes, you need to have a paid account. I have not gotten a chance to test the feature with a free account yet.


Variable Types


Variables can be of the following types:


- color: For color values.

- number: For numeric values such as spacing.

- boolean: For true/false values.

- string: For textual values.


Values


Each variable type can contain values defined for each mode. Values can be direct (e.g., a hex code for colors) or referenced from another variable using the format `CollectionName:VariableName/PropertyName`.


## Example JSON


Here is an example JSON file for a color and spacing collection:


{
"collections": [
{
"name": "Colors",
"modes": ["Default"],
"variables": {
"Barn-Red": {
"50": {
"type": "color",
"values": { "Default": "#ffe6e6" }
},
"950": {
"type": "color",
"values": { "Default": "#3c0202" }
}
}
}
},
{
"name": "Spacing Tokens",
"modes": ["Default"],
"variables": {
"spacing": {
"0": { "type": "number", "values": { "Default": 0 } },
"768": { "type": "number", "values": { "Default": 768 } }
},
"padding": {
"sm": {
"type": "number",
"values": { "Default": "Spacing Tokens:spacing/4" }
}
}
}
}
]
}


Importing Variables


To import variables into Figma:


1. Prepare Your JSON File: Construct your JSON file according to the structure detailed above, including all necessary variable collections.

2. Use the Plugin: Open the plugin in Figma and use the import function to select and load your JSON file. The plugin will parse the JSON and create the corresponding variables in Figma.


Exporting Variables


To export variables from Figma:


1. Select Collection: Use the plugin interface to select the collection you wish to export.

2. Choose Color Format: Specify the color format for your export (Hex, RGB, HSL, with or without alpha).

3. Export: Initiate the export process, and the plugin will generate a JSON file representing the current state of the selected variables in the chosen color format. This file can be used in other projects or shared with team members.


Tips for Effective Usage


- Consistency is Key: Maintain consistent naming conventions for your collections and variables to simplify management and referencing.

- Leverage Referencing: Use references to link variables, enabling a scalable and easily updatable design system.

- Regular Exports: Regularly export your variable collections to keep backups and ensure that team members are working with the most current design tokens.

accepted.name: Kyle Gagnon
accepted.description:
Hello!
I am a software engineer in the process of learning UI/UX.

plugins.tagline: Create, import, and export Figma variables with ease!

plugins.name: Screenshot Resizer
plugins.description:
Screenshot Resizer allows you to downscale your screenshots from physical size to logical size. Screenshot Resizer is able to handle multiple selections and downscale to their logical size at the same time.


Why would we need to have a logical size? We design by using the logical sizes of the devices and on Figma under the Prototype tab all the devices are located with their logical sizes. When you need to import a screenshot, you do not need to downscale manually your screenshot according to the device's scale factor anymore.

Select the screenshot frame and run the plugin, enjoy!

plugins.name: Spotlight Search
plugins.description:
Light plugin for fast navigation in your project. Find and jump to any Page, Frame, Component, Layer. That's it!

With the Recents section, you can quickly switch between 2-5 things to which you jumped before. Use arrow keys and return (enter on Win) to move inside the project without lifting your hands from the keyboard.

Pro tip: launch plugin with Run last plugin shortcut ‚å• ‚åò P.

I believe you are quite smart to remember the names of layers and pages. So what is the point of losing your mind finding them in the layers panel, right?

plugins.name: figma2code.ai | Figma to code: Android Compose | iOS SwiftUI | Flutter | React/Next.js | Vue | HTML
plugins.description:
Figma2Code: Transform Designs into Code Instantly

Figma2Code leverages cutting-edge AI technology to convert your Figma designs into production-ready code with a single click. This revolutionary tool boosts productivity by 10X, eliminating repetitive tasks for developers and empowering teams to focus on innovation. It's the ultimate solution for saving time and enhancing efficiency in both individual and collaborative workflows.


Key Features of Figma2Code

  1. High-Quality Code: Adapts to your coding style by analyzing existing code and reusing codes to produce clean, consistent results.
  2. Developer-Friendly Naming: Automatically generates intuitive variable names, enhancing code readability and maintainability.
  3. Vision Engine: Leverages advanced visual analysis to understand UI components.
  4. Layer Optimization: Recognizes and merges layers intelligently, ensuring clean and maintainable code.


Supported Frameworks

Figma2Code supports Android Jetpack Compose, iOS SwiftUI, Flutter, React, Next.js, Vue.js, HTML, CSS, Tailwind, and more!


Demo Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1CnwNtU1N_I


Data Security

Your designs are completely secure with Figma2Code. They are accessible only to you and will never be shared or used for other purposes. Like ChatGPT, Figma2Code is trained on internal datasets, ensuring complete confidentiality. Safeguarding your creative assets and privacy is our top priority.


Risk-Free Experience

Try Figma2Code with zero risk! Our free plan allows new users to explore the product without any payment or credit card requirements.


Questions or Suggestions

We value your input! Let us know how we can make Figma2Code even better for you. Contact us at support@figma2code.ai.


Learn More

Discover how Figma2Code can revolutionize your design-to-development workflow at figma2code.ai.
plugins.tagline: The ultimate AI tool for 10X engineers

plugins.name: Effect.app ‚Äî Real-time Image & Video Effects
plugins.description:
Add real-time, stackable effects to any frame without leaving Figma.


Effect.app for Figma embeds our browser-based effect engine directly in the plugin panel, so every edit stays on the canvas.


One-click workflow: Select a frame ‚Üí open the plugin ‚Üí tweak ‚Üí Export.

A new, fully styled frame appears underneath the source.


Local & secure ‚Äî All effects run in your browser; nothing ever leaves Figma.


Infinite combos ‚Äî Chain effects in any order and adjust parameters (strength, radius, tone curves, etc.) in real time.


Available Effects

RGB Shift, CRT screen, Led screen, Halftone screen, Vignette, Stripes, Noise (Grain).

Blurs: Circular blur, Gaussian blur, Motion blur, Radial blur, Sharpen, Zoom blur

Color: Color balance, Color matrix, Color temperature, Exposure, Hue/Saturation, Levels, Map to Gradient, Monochrome, Dither, RGB Gain, Contrast

Distort: Cubify, Glitch, Perspective, Pinch, Polar to rectangular, Rectangular to polar, Ripple, Transform, Swirl


Coming soon ‚Äì Presets

Save your effect stack, drop the URL in a comment, and anyone on the team can recreate the exact look in one click‚Äîperfect for brand systems.


How to use

  1. Select a frame.
  2. Run Effect.app from Plugins ‚Üí Design Tools.
  3. Tweak effect order & settings in the side panel.
  4. Export‚Äîa rendered copy is added to the canvas.


Built by a tiny team obsessed with real-time graphics and a friction-free design flow.

plugins.name: Variables Manager
plugins.description:
Variables Manager is a free, simple, easy to use tool to extract and manipulate your Figma variables.


With Variables Manager, you're no longer bound by the constraints of navigating through multiple collections to find and adjust variables. Instead, imagine having all your variables neatly organized in one place, ready for you to view and edit with ease.


Want to get to your variables quickly?

  1. Open a Figma file that has variables.
  2. Launch Variables Manager and you'll get a listing of all variables used in the file.
  3. Added/removed variables in your file? Simply update the view by using the Refresh function.
  4. Copy and paste the table of variables into another spreadsheet as required.


Features


Viewing string variables across collections

Variables Manager extract and display all the string variables across your collections. This is especially useful for auditing all the variables and the values which are nested in multiple collections, and helps with exchanges with content designers.

plugins.name: You Name It
plugins.description:
This plugin is designed to simplify naming in Figma while maintaining consistency across your design projects. The goal is to make it easy to create naming conventions that can be effortlessly applied to your nodes, allowing you to batch rename them in no time. I hope you enjoy using it!


Just start typing: { and you get the list of variables in the UI.


Available Variables:

  • {width} - Replaces with the node's width.
  • {height} - Replaces with the node's height.
  • {layerType} - Replaces with the node's type (e.g., Frame, Rectangle, Text).
  • {layerName} - This placeholder will be replaced with the original name of the node as it is at the time of applying the naming convention. Note that if you apply a new naming convention to a node that has already been renamed with this plugin, {layerName} will refer to the renamed name of the node, not the original name the node had when it was first created. This is because {layerName} captures the name of the node at the moment you press the rename button, whether that name is the node's original name or a name generated by a previous use of the YouNameIT plugin.
  • {index} - Replaces with the index of the current node in the list of linked nodes.
  • {date} - Replaces with the current date in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
  • {alphabet} - Replaces with a letter from the English alphabet (cycles from a-z and then starts over) based on the node's index.
  • {fileName} - Replaces with the Figma file's name.
  • {weekNumber} - Replaces with the current week number.
  • {pageName} - Replaces with the name of the page where the node is located.
  • {sectionName} - Advanced Section Naming Feature: You can now specify particular sections in their naming convention using the {sectionName=number} syntax. For example, {sectionName=1} will replace this placeholder with the name of the first section parent of the node. This allows for more controlled and precise naming based on the node's position in the section hierarchy.
  • Cycling Through Section Names: In cases where {sectionName} is used multiple times but there are fewer parent sections than the number of placeholders, the plugin will cycle back through the section names. This ensures that all {sectionName} placeholders are filled, reusing the names from the closest section down to the furthest.


The legacy version is no longer available.


Happy renaming! üéâ


Ps.

If you have any suggestions or encounter any issues, please don't hesitate to get in touch.
plugins.tagline: Effortlessly rename bulk items with variables ü§ô

plugins.name: Zine Maker
plugins.description:
Create templates to edit zines in page-order and print zines to cut and fold.


You can use this plugin to generate zine templates. Templates will lay out zine spreads in expected page order, with a component for each zine page. Place your content into these components.


Separately, Zine Maker will generate printer page layouts using instances of those components.


Each side of an 8.5x11 printer page contains 4 zine pages, laid out so they print in the correct order. Print double-sided, cut, and fold to create your zine.


Because zines are created double-sided, any increment of zine pages that is not a multiple of 8 will round up so that printer pages are printed correctly.

plugins.name: ReBo
plugins.description:
ReBo is a simple Figma utility allowing you to precisely place, and organize guides to your frames!


 Features Include...

‚ú® Easily add mirrored margin bounds to your frames

‚ú® Create Columns for a quick column (or row) grid

‚ú® Save your guides for use later

‚ú® Quick-guide shortcuts to add center margins

‚ú® Multi-frame guides clear

‚ú® KeyCombo! Control + Shift + S to save your current guides


Adding guides

By default, your margins are locked, meaning anything you input on a "Left" margin, will mirror the "Right" side. Same is true for Rows with "Top" & "Bottom". Once you've entered your desired values, Make sure you have a Frame selected, then hit Add Guides. That's it!


You can also add columns, and it will respect margins you have placed, if any.


Saving guides

If adding these settings (columns and margins) are part of your normal workflow, you can save these settings by click the ‚ñ¥ on the bottom right corner or press Control+ Shift + S to bring up the Save Dialog. Give your guides a name, and bam! it should now appear under Saved Guides.


--

If you encounter any bugs or usability issues, feel free to DM me on twitter @ltrademark, or leave a comment below.

plugins.name: Figma for Print
plugins.description:
+ About DPI, PDF export features requested


  1. DPI: Figma‚Äôs vector objects are resolution-independent, free from DPI for shapes or text. However, if you‚Äôre using images, be sure they‚Äôre at the correct DPI to get your desired pixel dimensions. I'm exploring new features, such as one-click DPI checks or image resampling, to streamline this process.
  2. Export Frames to PDF: To export multiple frames as a single PDF, open the Figma menu, go to File, and select Export frames to PDF.


Happy print works for you all. Feedback always appreciated.


Perfect Frames for Print in Figma


Are you a UI/UX designer who dabbles in print design? Same here.

I created this plugin because I got tired of wasting money on expensive software just to design a few pages. you can create print-ready artboards(frames) using various units of measurement in Figma with this simple plugin:


  1. Check object size: See the exact dimensions of your selected object in flexible units.
  2. Flexible units: Instantly switch between mm, cm, inches, px, and more.
  3. Custom layouts: Set custom sizes, margins, and bleed guides to fit your needs.
  4. Convenient presets: Use standard sizes like A4, Letter, A5, and more.


It's for free. I might add new features in future updates.

plugins.name: Color Copier

Simply select any layer with a solid fill and run the plugin to copy its color value.

Supported Formats:
- RGB
- Hex
- HSL
- HSV
Note: Hex color doesn't support transparency. Semi-transparent colors are copied as if they were fully opaque.

Choose which format(s) to copy by opening Preferences from the plugin menu. If you select multiple formats, they'll be on separate lines when you paste the value. Preferences are saved to the file so that you can your collaborators are speaking the same language.

This plugin was is open source: https://github.com/jtini/color-copier. Please feel free to suggest improvements!

Supported Formats:
- RGB
- Hex
- HSL
- HSV
Note: Hex color doesn't support transparency. Semi-transparent colors are copied as if they were fully opaque.

Choose which format(s) to copy by opening Preferences from the plugin menu. If you select multiple formats, they'll be on separate lines when you paste the value. Preferences are saved to the file so that you can your collaborators are speaking the same language.

This plugin was is open source: https://github.com/jtini/color-copier. Please feel free to suggest improvements!
3798.release_notes:
This version is optimized for speed.

The plugin UI was converted from React to Svelte. This makes the plugin run faster, even when the UI doesn't need to be interacted with.

plugins.name: Fix Frame Numbers
plugins.description:
Rename frames instantly on Figma by removing large numbers from frame labels.


How to use?

Open any Figma file and run the plugin.

Type in any number in the input provided and click 'Run'. The plugin will instantly rename all frame labels with numbers larger than this one.

For example, if 40000 is the input, a frame labelled "Frame 40506" is renamed to "Frame 506".


When to use?

Sometimes, when working across multiple files, a frame with a large number in its label can be accidentally or intentionally pasted into a file. This causes an issue where all frames created subsequently in the file are named with large numbers, causing confusion and annoyance.

For example, a frame labelled "Frame 1000000000" will cause all subsequent frames to have large numbers in their name.

Use this plugin to resolve such issues.


Feedback and comments are much appreciated.
plugins.tagline: Rename frames instantly on Figma by removing large numbers from frame labels

plugins.name: GuideGuide
plugins.description:
GuideGuide lets you quickly and easily manipulate guides to speed up layout and create grids, with more power and flexibility than the built in tools.


An annual subscription is required, but you can start a 14 day free trial without signing up. Students and teachers can use GuideGuide for free. GuideGuide is available for most of your favorite design tools and your license unlocks it in all supported apps.


Features:


  • Create the basics, like margins, columns, rows, and gutters.
  • Be lazy with quick edge and midpoint guides.
  • Flex with gutter midpoints or column margins.
  • Get weird with the Fibonacci sequence and the golden ratio.
  • Save presets for future use.


History:


GuideGuide started in 2010 as a side project in the days of Photoshop web design. Many years and many apps later, it‚Äôs still independent software built by me, Cameron McEfee, living the independent developer dream. Thanks for your support!
plugins.tagline: Powerful grids and guides in your favorite design tools

Gemini Image Assistant is a powerful Figma plugin that leverages Google Gemini AI technology to help designers intelligently edit and process images.

Key Features:

Smart Image Editing: Edit and process images through natural language descriptions

Multi-image Composition: Support relationship processing between two images, such as style transfer, element composition, etc.

Instant Preview: Efficient image preloading mechanism, click to preview available images

Multi-round Editing: Support multiple consecutive edits on the same image for fine-tuning effects

How to Use:

Select one or two image layers

Enter a natural language description of your desired editing effect

Get AI-generated images, automatically created next to the original layer

Advantages:

Full support for both Chinese and English interfaces

Intuitive and clean user interface design

Efficient image processing workflow, reducing waiting time

Locally stored API keys for security and reliability

Requires a Gemini API key to use. Suitable for designers, illustrators, and anyone who needs quick creative image processing.

plugins.name: Yasou - Team Video Calls
plugins.description:
Catch up with your team instantly üéâ with the Yasou plugin through video calls.

Here is your first ever ü•á Figma plugin to do video calls with all those interacting into the same Figma file. The Yasou plugin, enables teams that work together on a file to do audio or video calls and run workshops efficiently. Suitable for rapid team communication, share screening, instant feedback and workshops. ü§ôüèø

Instructions - How to use the Plugin:

Just one from your team has to initiate the plugin:
      1. Install the plugin.
      2. Run the plugin
      3. Enter meeting name and click OK

All the other users in the file like other editors, owners, admins and viewers will then see a generated Image inside the Figma file.
For each one to join the call:

      1. Select the generated image
      2. Join the call by Clicking the Plugin at the bottom right side of Figma.
      3. Enjoy.

Disclaimer: This project is open source and a proof of concept. We are not really sure if it is useful, so we need your opinion. Use it and help us make Yassu even better or hit just us with the hard truth and tell us to drop it.

To give feedback for this plugin, please use this google form right here, anonymously: https://forms.gle/ak7Ki5FBHpnJeHDw8

Learn more about us: www.quintessential.gr
Read our blog: https://medium.com/quintessential-sft
GitHub code: https://github.com/Quintessential-SFT/Yasou-Figma

plugins.name: Data Merge
plugins.description:
Need to generate a bunch of certificates or business cards? Do you miss Word's Mail Merge or InDesign's Data Merge in Figma? Want to leverage all the Figma goodness and comfort to create your certificate/business card/anything else's template and don't want to manually duplicate frames and copy and paste all your data?


Data Merge was made exactly for that, just:

  1. create your template
  2. name the layers the same way as the column names of your data (e.g. Name, Surname, Country ‚Äì each a separate text layer)
  3. copy your data (plugin expects tab-delimited CSV ‚Äî but that's exactly what's in your clipboard when you copy from Google Sheets)
  4. paste it to plugin's UI
  5. hit Create frames
  6. voil√†, frames with merged data appear ‚ú®


üí° Tip: Put things like Name and Surname in an Autolayout to concatenate them

üí° Tip 2: Make your template a component, that way you can still adjust all your generated frames in bulk! ‚ú® (That makes it actually even better than the continuous re-generating InDesign whenever you changed the template hehe) (on the other hand, this plugin doesn't have a templating system yet, it's made for simplicity).


If the plugin helped you or want to motivate me to improve it, you can buy me a coffee ‚òïÔ∏èü•∞


Notes


Please note this is a total MVP which was originally made to help my colleagues at #HolkyzMarketingu and save their time. Some edge cases might not be cared for, I haven't heavy-tested it on large data sets and so on. On the other hand, the plugin is completely free and forever will be, it has no network access and I really did it because my colleagues needed it and thought it could be useful for other folks, too, nothing else ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è


I plan to continuously improve the plugin by polishing its UX, handling edge cases and other things, but my schedule is busy, so can't promise anything. If you want me to though, a supportive comment will be highly appreciated ü´∂


Roadmap üöÄ

  1. support prefixes (specify that your text layers begin with "#" for example)
  2. rename layers according to specified field
  3. rename layers according to a given expression
  4. better templating system (far in the future)
  5. generate unique QR codes (very far in the future)
  6. you tell me :)

Continuously: better UX (checking CSV on paste, informing user about matched text layers and column names...)



Feedback & Development

Any suggestions and feedback are appreciated üôè If you're interested or even want to contribute, here's the plugin's repo on GitHub.


Fun fact: this plugin was mostly coded by ChatGPT4, but I did contribute here and there with my dusty coding knowledge, provided some optimisation ideas and was a very annoying product owner to say the least üë©‚Äçüíª

accepted.name: Kl√°ra Scholleov√°
accepted.description: A product designer (ex-Oracle) from Prague/Pardubice üá®üáø with background in music and coding. Sometimes too honest, but meaning well. ü´∂

I plan to continuously improve the plugin by polishing its UX, handling edge cases and other things, but my schedule is busy, so can't promise anything. If you want me to though, a supportive comment will be highly appreciated ü´∂


Roadmap üöÄ

  1. support prefixes (specify that your text layers begin with "#" for example)
  2. rename layers according to specified field
  3. rename layers according to a given expression
  4. better templating system (far in the future)
  5. generate unique QR codes (very far in the future)
  6. you tell me :)

Continuously: better UX (checking CSV on paste, informing user about matched text layers and column names...)



Feedback & Development

Any suggestions and feedback are appreciated üôè If you're interested or even want to contribute, here's the plugin's repo on GitHub.


Fun fact: this plugin was mostly coded by ChatGPT4, but I did contribute here and there with my dusty coding knowledge, provided some optimisation ideas and was a very annoying product owner to say the least üë©‚Äçüíª

Thanks Alexander Kim (github @oklex) for the PR!

plugins.name: Ovvverrrflowww
plugins.description:
Ovvverrrflowww is a dynamic Figma plugin designed to distribute elements randomly within selected frames. Perfect for designers looking to add a touch of randomness and creativity to their layouts, Ovvverrrflowww makes it easy to create unique compositions with minimal effort.


Key Features:


  1. Random Distribution: Scatter elements randomly by adjusting their x and y coordinates, rotation, and stacking order.
  2. Multiple Frames Support: Apply random distribution across one or multiple frames simultaneously.
  3. Customizable Parameters: Configure distribution parameters using the quick actions menu (cmd + p) for precise control over the randomness.


How to Use:


  1. Select Frame(s): Choose a frame or multiple frames containing the elements you want to distribute.
  2. Run the Plugin: Run Ovvverrrflowww to initiate the random distribution process.
  3. Enjoy the Results: Watch as your elements are randomly positioned, rotated, and reordered within the selected frame(s).


Tips:


  1. Quick Actions Menu: Access the quick actions menu (cmd + p) to configure parameters like randomness intensity and rotation range.
  2. Experiment: Try running the plugin multiple times for different distribution patterns. Use opt+cmd+p for quick access.


Unleash your creativity with Ovvverrrflowww and bring a fresh, randomized look to your Figma designs

accepted.name: Sergey Lisovskiy
accepted.description: Designer & frontent developer

plugins.tagline: Distribute objects randomly within the frame

plugins.name: Scribe - Dynamic data in seconds
plugins.description:
Meet Scribe ‚Äì The Mail Merge for Figma for crafting data-driven graphics.


Scribe can help you automate and mass generate frames with real dynamic data!


===

Let me walk you through an example. You are Albus Dumbledore and you need to generate acceptance letters for the new batch at Hogwarts. The new batch has 40 students and Professor McGonagall has already handed off the letter to you on Figma.


Now, you are definitely not going to change the name and export the letter 40 times. That's too brutal. That's too na√Øve.

Let Scribe cast its magic.

===


And with this new and upgraded version ‚Äì Scribe is more powerful than ever.


Here's what Scribe can do:

üíø Import data from a CSV or a Google Sheet

üéû Generate from multiple frames in one go

üîí No more publicly published Google Sheets. Scribe Bot can now be added to your Sheet and Drive as a collaborator

üí¨ Replace the content of Text Layers

üóØ Partially replace the content of Text Layers

üì∏ Replace fill of Frame Layer with images

‚ö°Ô∏è Transform layers with Customisations

‚òÅÔ∏è Special integration with Google Drive to make managing images painless

üì¶ Customise your exports

üèé Under the hood, Scribe is rewritten from scratch with performance at the centre stage. On my machine (MacBook Pro 2020, M1), It generated 1000 frames with Text Layers in about 724 seconds. That's 0.72 seconds per frame. That's ffaasstt!


How to use:

‚úèÔ∏è Name the layers

The layer names of text layers must begin with a # followed by the field name of the Data Source column that they'd be substituted by.

For example: For a Data Source containing names of people in the column name , the name of the text layer in Figma would be #name. Naming is case-sensitive.

There are plenty more customisations available in the documentation.


üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Run Scribe

Select your frame and run Scribe.


üìÄ Import data

You can import the data from a CSV file or a Google Sheet.


‚öôÔ∏è Configure and scribe

Tweak some settings to make the setup really personal. Finally, scribe and have your graphics handcrafted and exported to you in mere seconds.


Why Scribe?

There's so much Scribe can do.

- Generate certificates for the awesome attendees of your conference

- Perform a batch generation of coupons

- Create personalised gratitude-full letters for all your small-business supporters


Give Scribe a try if you want to:

- Create beautiful data-driven graphics in a fraction of the time it takes to do by hand

- Automate the process of creating a bunch of graphics with real data


There's a Kitchen Sink available here to showcase the power of Scribe: 

üëæ https://youtu.be/EOWnPWuPNPI


And here's the entire documentation:

üìù https://docs.scribe.ishanchhabra.com
plugins.tagline: The Mail Merge for Figma for crafting data-driven graphics.

plugins.name: EXAT ‚Äî Pattern Generator
plugins.description:
EXAT

Customize and generate optical illusion grids inspired by mid-century masters.


How to Use

Run the plugin and set the desired parameters. Click the Insert button at the bottom of the Controls panel. EXAT will insert your custom visual on the canvas.


Interface


Controls

  1. Grid Size: Adjusts the number of shapes across the grid, both horizontally and vertically.
  2. Shape Width: Changes the width of each individual shape in the grid.
  3. Shape Height: Changes the height of each individual shape in the grid.
  4. Border Radius: Sets the corner roundness for each shape.
  5. Inner Spacing: Adjusts the spacing between shapes inside the grid.
  6. Outer Spacing: Modifies the margin or space around the grid.
  7. Line Count: Determines the number of lines inside each shape.
  8. Line Spacing: Controls the distance between each line within the shape, affecting how densely the lines are packed.
  9. Min Line Width: Specifies the minimum thickness of lines inside the shapes.
  10. Max Line Width: Specifies the maximum thickness of lines inside the shapes.


Appearance

  1. Line Width Pattern: Controls the variation of line thickness‚Äîoptions include thinnest lines in the center, on the outer edges, or randomly distributed.
  2. Base Rotation: Sets the initial rotation angle of the lines within each shape.
  3. Rotation Increment: Determines how much each subsequent shape is rotated relative to the previous one.
  4. Rotation Pattern: Specifies the pattern of rotation across the grid, including spiral, alternate, or random rotation.
  5. Background Color: Sets the background color of the grid.
  6. Line Color: Sets the color of the lines inside each shape.

accepted.name: Luka Marr
accepted.description: Design @ MoonPay

plugins.tagline: Customize and generate visual grids and patterns inspired by mid-century masters.

plugins.name: Easy Proto
plugins.description:
Presenting Pro Proto, redefining better prototyping in Figma. Designed to supercharge your design workflow.


Maximize Your A/B Prototyping

Want to experiment with diverse layouts or user flows? Empower your testing and presentations with our dual-prototyping feature, allowing you to run two concurrent prototypes side-by-side, and they can be from different design files!


No more tab jumping

Enjoy the convenience of a floating prototype window layered over your editor. It allows you to swiftly test, iterate, and refine your designs without the disruption of swapping between separate Figma tabs or files.


Resizable and Collapsable

Need more room for your editor? Freely resize the window or instantly collapse the window. Done with your edits? Expand your window back with a single button click.


Auto-Reopen Functionality

Swiftly resume your prototyping sessions without missing a beat. Our Auto-Reopen feature ensures your prototypes from your last session are ready to be further refined or presented instantly.


The Power of Convenience

With Easy Proto, simply select a frame in your design file or open prototype flows from the active design file. The feature will automatically initiate the prototypes.


Ready to Take Your Prototyping to the Next Level?


Easy Proto is set to redefine your prototyping experience in Figma. Go Pro, and unlock the future of efficient and intuitive prototyping today!




Support me

Additionally, If you find the Easy Proto plugin valuable and want to support its development, please consider becoming a subscriber or supporter on Ko-fi! Your support helps me continue to create and maintain useful tools for you and the figma design community. Visit my Ko-fi page at https://ko-fi.com/joshiee to learn more and show your support.
plugins.tagline: The better multi-screen prototyping experience

plugins.name: Export to Elm
plugins.description:
This plugin allows you to export a selection as Elm code.
The generated code will be for the `elm/svg` package, so make sure you have it installed in your Elm project.

Usage:

* Select the object that you would like to export as Elm code
* Run `Export to Elm` from the Plugins menu
* Apply optional `Svg` or `Svg.Attributes` module aliases
